Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(x) = e^{iwx} \\) where \\( w \\) is a real constant and \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit. We assess the effect of the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) on this function, given by the integral \\( \\mathcal{F}(z)(k) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{iwx} e^{-ikx} dx \\), analyzing both the direct transformation and its inversion.

If an additional phase-shift operation \\( h(x) = e^{iqx} \\) where \\( q \\) is real, is applied to \\( z(x) \\) before the Fourier transform, will the result still be a delta function at \\( k = w \\)?
Explanation: Applying the phase shift changes the function to \\( z(x)h(x) = e^{i(w+q)x} \\). The resultant Fourier transform will be \\( 2\\pi \\delta(k - (w + q)) \\), thus shifting the delta function to be centered at \\( k = w + q \\), not \\( k = w \\).
